DOC.HEAD: U.S. Senators Believe Government is Seeking Jesuit Killers
With AM-Salvador-Christmas
DOC.TEXT: Two U.S. senators met rightist President Alfredo Cristiani on Monday and asserted that his government is committed to finding out who massacred six Jesuit priests. Dennis DeConcini of Arizona and Bob Graham of Florida, both Democrats, told a news conference they expected continued U.S. support for El Salvador. However, DeConcini said it was possible aid would be cut off if the investigation shows military involvement in the Nov. 16 killings. The slayings of the leadership of the Jesuit-run Central American University prompted some U.S. legislators to call for reappraisal of the $1.5 million in aid that Washington provides daily to El Salvador. The Roman Catholic Church and the Jesuits have concluded military men were almost certainly responsible for the massacre of the Jesuits, their housekeeper and her daughter. A witness has testified she saw men in army uniforms near the priests' on-campus residence shortly before the fatal shots were heard. ``We believe President Cristiani and military leaders are prepared to have any and all outside assistance to certify the exhaustiveness and thoroughness of the investigtion wherever it leads, including if it leads to the military,'' said DeConcini. FBI and Scotland Yard investigators, as well as detectives from Spain, are collaborating in the inquiry. DeConcini said he would be ``flabbergasted'' if the investigation found high-level military responsibility. He said if such involvement were proven, a cutoff in U.S. aid ``would certainly be a possibility.'' If a small armed forces contingent acting on its own is found to be responsible, an aid cutoff ``would still be a possibility, but not very likely,'' he said. ``If the government continues its forceful and aggressive investigation, support in Congress will be maintained,'' DeConcini said. The Salvadoran government has offered a reward of $250,000 for information leading to the prosecution of those responsible for the massacre. The Jesuits were killed during a renewed offensive by leftist guerrillas trying to overthrow the government. Right-wing forces often view church people as guerrilla allies.
